didoss@... wrote:
> 
> 
> I generally test that it is not null,...

The Java Language Specification states that a constructor cannot return 
null, so don't test for that. That assertion can never fail.

> and possibly for anything else 
> that might occur in the constructor (like how you passed in a length). 
> If you are trying to test that you can actually create an ArrayList of 
> your user defined type - as in your example - I would also test that you 
> really can add an object of that type, and that you cannot add an object 
> that is not of that type,...I don't want to test the ArrayList itself, 
> since I trust Sun has done that, but I would want to test that it 
> correctly recognizes what is and isn't my custom type.

To the original poster, how would you know that the code /did not/ work 
properly? What kinds of things do you think could go wrong with this line:

reqFieldTypes = new ArrayList<FieldType>(fieldTypes.length);
